article_metadata.description: Regarding "Family fighting cystic fibrosis forced to battle insurer, too" (Page A1, Sunday), the article on insurers controlling access to needed medical care should be a reminder that the Affordable Care Act was no more than a small step in the right direction.  Once, perhaps years ago, Americans were a generous and compassionate people, but these traits seemed to have vanished in the face of an inordinately expensive medical care industry.  Can't we decide as a people that all Americans have a right to decent medical care in a single, well-run system that serves everyone's health care needs?  Albert Schweitzer, a German physician who gave up his comfortable life in Europe to treat Africans in the early-to-mid-1900s, saw the beginnings of ethical decline before his death in 1965.  Research initiatives in CF are covered by donation, foundations and grants from the National Institutes of Health, not patient visits.
